item.title: Welcome to My Scrolls
item.description: [! important]+ Scrolls My name is Srikar V. I have always been a fan of these digital gardens, blogs I see online all beautifully structured and done.

item.title: types of graph edges
item.description: Graph Edges Captures We all know the main type of edges and they are directed and undirected edges. But we also need to know that there are several other types of edges that branch out from these two but have different significance based on the graphs.

item.title: two-pointers
item.description: Two-Pointers Summary Moving 2 pointers in a array based on a condition Used when you want to optimise a O(n^2) time â†’ O(n) time and O(n) space â†’ O(1) space ...

item.title: trees
item.description: Trees Summary Trees are abstract non-sequential data structures that are really just a bunch of nodes and links that are connected to one another. trees are undirected and connected acyclic graphs, they are acyclic because they do not contain cycles or loops.

item.title: tree depth traversals
item.description: Tree Depth Traversals Summary Since trees are unstructured data structures and unique. The way we can access the nodes is by traversing in a unique way, one such way is to traverse by depth.

item.title: tree level order traversal
item.description: Level Order Traversal Summary Level Order Traversal as the name suggests, we traverse the tree by visiting every node in each level. We always go from left to right and hence it is also called breadth first search.

item.title: tree depth traversal use cases
item.description: Depth Traversal Use cases Summary We know tree depth traversals have different ordering and each of these ordering have their own unique use cases that help us for efficient operations ...

item.title: tim sort
item.description: Tim Sort Summary Tim sort is a hybrid, stable sorting algorithm designed by Tim Peters in 2002, it combines merge and insertion sort to efficiently sort ...

item.title: strings
item.description: Strings Summary Very similar to Arrays because they are sequence of characters while Arrays are sequence of a single data type. Common Things Common data structures for looking up strings - Trie/Prefix tree - Suffix tree Common algorithms for searching substrings - Rabin-Karp Algorithm - KMP Time Complexity OperationBig-OAccessO(1)SearchO(n)InsertO(n)RemoveO(n) Operations Involving Another String OperationBig-ONoteFind substringO(n.m)This is the most naive case.
